topic: How to Make Homemade Vinegar from Fruit Scraps

sources.title: How to Make Free Apple Scrap Vinegar
sources.author: Anne-Marie Bonneau
key_facts: Combine apple scraps, water and sugar in a large, wide-mouth glass or ceramic vessel
Cover with a thin cloth to allow air exposure - vinegar needs oxygen unlike most ferments
Stir several times a day for first few days, then once daily after bubbling starts
Fermentation takes about 2 weeks total - strain fruit when bubbling subsides
Bottle when no carbonation detected - burp occasionally to prevent explosions
Vinegar keeps indefinitely at room temperature
If tap water has chlorine, let it sit open for a day to dissipate
Cold (freezing) doesn't kill microbes, only puts them to sleep - frozen scraps work fine

sources.title: Apple Scrap Vinegar - Easy, Inexpensive Home Made Vinegar
sources.author: Unknown
key_facts: Use 1 quart fruit scraps, 1 quart warm water, 1/2 cup sugar ratio
Keep at room temperature 65-85째F and stir daily for 7-10 days
Initial smell is alcoholic (yeast producing alcohol) then shifts to acidic vinegar smell
Strain at 7-10 days before fruit breaks up and makes mealy vinegar
Continue fermenting 2-3 more weeks with cloth cover after straining
Use non-chlorinated water - chlorine kills vinegar yeast
Never seal tightly during fermentation - CO2 buildup can cause explosions
Sunlight kills the yeast - keep out of direct sunlight

sources.title: Apple Scrap Vinegar Recipe
sources.author: Laurie Neverman
key_facts: Recipe: 1 quart apple scraps, 1/2 cup sugar, 1 quart warm water
Optional: 2 tablespoons raw apple cider vinegar to jumpstart ferment
Use glass, food grade plastic, or stainless steel containers - non-reactive
Stir daily and push scraps below liquid to prevent mold
Strain apple chunks after about a week and compost them
Ferment additional 2-3 weeks after straining
Can use for cooking, cleaning, pets, or health purposes

summary: Research confirms that homemade vinegar from fruit scraps is a simple fermentation process requiring only fruit scraps, water, and sugar. The process takes 3-4 weeks total: 7-10 days with fruit scraps (stirring daily), then 2-3 weeks after straining. Key success factors include using non-chlorinated water, maintaining 65-85째F temperature, daily stirring to prevent mold, and keeping the vessel covered with cloth (not sealed) to allow oxygen while keeping pests out.
